blocks.value: The Leader of the Jerusalem Church

Tradition teaches that James the Less was the brother of the Apostle Jude, and also a relative of Jesus Christ. He is also called "James the Just" due to his renowned holiness. St. Paul tells us (Galatians 1:19) that James was one of the pillars of the Church. According to the tradition of the early Church, St. James was the first bishop of Jerusalem and presided over the first Church council.

The account of his martyrdom is vivid. The Jews came up to James and asked him to publicly disavow Jesus. They took him to the top of the Temple and told him to speak against Jesus. Standing high upon the Temple, James loudly preached the faith in Jesus and when he was finished the angry mob threw him off the Temple. The fall did not kill him so they stoned him. Finally, a fuller (one who thickens cloth by moistening, heating and pressing) took the club used to beat garments and gave James a fatal blow to the head.
